description.text:
These are the parts for the Minecraft Nightlight I built for my daughter.

Built around an Arduino with accelerometer to detect when it's picked up, and LEDs for lighting up the room.

The Base Station is to contain a wireless charging module with alignment magnets so the cube can be left on charge when it's not being carried.

I printed this on a single extruder printer so the walls of the cube are done in two pieces, one solid and one in clear PLA that clips into the solid piece. I've included STL files for those with a multi-extruder printer to avoid having to friction fit pieces.

This project has been build and works just fine, but marked as WIP since I haven't yet finished the write-up.

author: J-Max

title: Tak - Two Sided Board and Pieces

description.text:
If you'd like one of these, check out my 3D Hub.

A double-sided Tak board (6x6 and 5x5), with playing pieces.

Glue small neodymium magnets in the corners of the board and base box. These magnets are surprisingly strong, so you'll need to alternate their poles so that one corner of the board has both magnets attracting each other with the positive ends facing the 6x6 side, the next corner with positive poles facing the 5x5, then facing 6x6 again, and finally 5x5 for the last corner. Do the same for the base, with positive facing up in the first corner, then down, up, down going around the corners. I hope that makes some sort of sense. I made a diagram, hope it helps get the point accross. Of course, if you don't intend to keep the board on the base when playing, you could always just place the magnets on one side of the board only and have all the poles facing the same way.

The base box has a reminder for the number of pieces to use for each board size, written in a bit of shorthand. 6:30/1, for example, means that when playing 6x6, use 30 stones and one capstone per player.

I also used a marker to mark of a 4x4 grid on the 6x6 side and a 3x3 grid on the 5x5 side.

The board is pretty large and just barely fits my Ultimaker 2+ bed: 7.25 x 7.25 inches (184.15 x 184.15 mm). You could scale things, but then you'd have to figure out what size you need for the magnets or just do without them.

Rules for Tak can be found here.

description.text:
Instructions on how to assemble are in the YouTube link below:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IQF7PLkAY8I&feature=youtu.be

UPDATE 3.0: I've decided to release the object files in .ipt form(Autodesk inventor format) so that you can you can tweak tolerances and improve designs by yourself. If you don't have Inventor, download a trial version and tweak it that way. Thanks for downloading my design!!!

UPDATE 2.0: There was a design problem that I didn't find until now (thank you Runkel!). SB should now allow the safe door to close flush. Sorry for not sorting this problem out sooner!

UPDATE 1.0: The safe Is now FINISHED! You should download ONE 1-KP file and then download the rest. The 1-KC files are now numbered as "1-KP-xx", the "xx" refers to it's specific key code (eg. You want your last combination number to be "5", so you will download "1-KC-5").

This combination safe has four combinations that are fully customizable to the user. The pictures and the STL files will look different as I have tweaked and improved the design since building the safe. I created this to stop my cat from peaking and stealing my money. Yes you read that right, my CAT!

You will need:
four M3.5(you may need to saw the length down to size)
Glue (most parts shouldn't require this)
Hammer(again, most parts shouldn't require this)
Pliers(explained below)

Tips:
The O-ring clips are a little hard to pry open by hand, but easily doable. They should click into place once fitted and can be taken off just as quickly.

The Notches on the code wheel(IKP and IKPR) may need to be sandwiched together with pliers, they're a tight fit and should not fall out once pressed.

Please Comment about any problems with assembling the safe or files.

Printer:

Velleman K8200

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

PLEASE READ!!!!

The model was designed with the consideration of tolerances, IT MAY FIT LOOSE WHEN YOU MAKE IT!

Please use glue if possible, but please comment if there's any problems!

My printer uses a 0.5mm extruder with a 0.3mm layer resolution. This causes my prints to be a little wider than designed, and hence why I made holes and connections wider.

title: 75mm micro quad frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
i found abs>pla, but i guess nylon or polycarbonate is even better. i use tpu for the feed

this copter is a blast to fly, flips & rolls very fast, insane yaw rates are possible. frame is tough and can take a hit. I tried with PLA first, but it is heavier and tends to shatter, even though it appears tougher.

Print at 100% infill to get maximum toughness. Weighs about 6g. use 380mAh batteries, ~4 minutes airtime.

dont go heaver than 12g per battery or you will really start to feel the weight. I found that 500mah lipos only give 30-45 seconds more flight time, but way slower throttle response!

title: Tangent Quadcopter Frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
THIS IS STILL A WORK IN PROGRESS!
3-29-17, added some supports. i kept breaking arms.

12-25-16 updated frame and camera mount, frame is a touch thicker and has better motor mounts. camera mount face has been shortened so it is not visible through the camera

I finally got this little hummer in the air and I can say that I am very happy with the parts combo!
just remember that this build is very tight! please let me know if you have any suggestions or requests.Thank you!

The Tangent is a micro brushless quadcopter frame. It is meant for use with brushless motors that have a 8.5mm mount hole spacing, such as the Racerstar 1103-8000kv or 10,000kv motors. It is meant to use a 20x20mm mounted fc (picoblx). I have not measured out or test fitted a 4 in 1 20x20 mounted esc yet.
The body, frame and camera mount can be printed with pla or abs.
I had the best luck printing the body right side up with support, but it can be printed upside down as well.
frame is printed right side up
camera mount is printed face down
the "tangent frame carbon" is for use with a cnc cutter if you so choose to cut it out.
and the battery strap is for a nano tech 2s 450 lipo.

The camera mount is your typical micro 600tvl camera

description.text:
I decided that it was finally time to organize the batteries in the junk drawer in the kitchen. This thing holds AA and AAA batteries, sorted by type and by whether they are charged or discharged. Obviously, the red section is for discharged batteries, while the green section is for charged ones.

The red color was obtained by putting a pause in after the top layer was printed at the 32mm mark, and changing the filament at that point. You can do this or skip it and get a single color print. Your choice.

I printed it with three shells, and 0% infill until the 28mm mark, where I changed to 10% infill to ensure that the top layers would print well.

author: Rich_H

title: Viper Trigger for Airsoft BAR-10, VSR-10 or other VSR style Airsoft rifles

description.text:
NOTE:
Download the flattened versions if you don't use Cura, if you use Cura then use the right click command "split object into parts", the model halves should lay flat after that.

This is an older project I prototyped a while back, it is a printable flat-faced trigger designed to fit a number of bolt-action airsoft rifles, including the Tokyo Marui VSR 10 and JG BAR 10, it may also fit other clone versions of the Tokyo Marui VSR series, but I have not been able to test this.

There are four versions of the trigger, each with a different design. They should all function the same, the only differences are aesthetic, choose the one you want on your gun.

This model was designed for use with a Wolverine Bolt or Mancraft HPA drop-in system. It will also work on a standard spring powered VSR or BAR rifle, but the seer on the top will not last nearly as long.

For conventional spring and Mancraft engine systems length of pull until the air gun fires should be around 5-8mm, if it's longer than that you can shave down the backside of the seer with a file or razor blade to shorten it, creating a "hair trigger" like effect.
For the wolverine bolt the extension on the right side actuates the microswitch, so you can shorten the trigger pull by either integrating a grub screw, or by gluing on shim materials to the face of the extension.

Printing instructions:

Print at 80-100% fill density (100% is recommended) at a scale of 102% to account for shrinkage (in PLA, ABS will likely need a similar number).
You will have to drill out the pivot hole using a 1/8" drill bit in order to get it to fit into the rifle, my suggestion is to twist the drill bit in to one half, add a few drops of superglue to the inside surface, then twist the other half onto the bit until the halves mate together; align them and let the superglue set, sand the edges and you should be ready to roll.

This is a small part so watch your temps or you may encounter warping issues.

description.text: In the spirit of the holiday season, I put a simple twist on the default rabbit that Meshmixer provides with their software. Based off of Rudolph from the original Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer movie from 1964, the Reindeer Rabbit has its own little reindeer antlers and a new nose. Yes, I realize this could just as easily be considered a Jackalope. Call it what you want. This is a quick print with minimal material (it's hollow) so you can make one for yourself or multiple to give as simple gifts to family and friends. Merry printing to all!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

0%

Notes:

I used Craftware to print this part. You can download it here for free https://craftunique.com/craftware. I like it better than Cura and it's worth trying out. I took screenshots of all my slicing settings in Craftware if you want to try printing it exactly the way I did. I also included the .cwprj and .gcode along with the .stl.
There is really no need to print this with any infill, however if you scale up the part it might be worth trying some infill. The trickiest part to print are the antlers. The ears aren't too difficult with the right supports. I used Makergeeks Maker Series PLA printing at 230 C for most of the print. I reduced the temperature to 215 C once it started printing the antlers to reduce drooping and stringing. I also slowed the speed to 70% for the antlers but it didn't seem to make any difference. You'll need as much cooling as possible for the antlers to get the best results. Because this is a relatively small print, it doesn't use much material and prints in about an hour. I printed it first using a 0.2mm layer height without changing the temperature or speed for the antlers and the only real difference was slightly less smooth antlers. Feel free to ask any questions or post some tips in the comments and please include a picture of your print if you make one. Thanks!

Use a heat gun or a lighter with a quick motion to remove/reduce and stringing left behind. My supports broke off cleanly and knife was used to remove any little nubs left behind from the support material.

description.text:
This is created in response to a math teacher's request for a 3D printable model for multiplication (K-8). It can be used to model both integers and fractions, depending on the choice of wording and definition of the whole.

Example 1: What is 3 x 5?
Example 2: What is the area ( in term of sq cm) of a rectangle that measures 3 cm by 5 cm?
Example 3: Assuming the board is 1 square unit. What is the area of a rectangle that is 3/12 unit by 5/12 unit?

Printer:

FlashForge Finder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Please use a higher infill rate for the slider for strength.
Put the two sliders carefully on the board. Please note one is slightly higher than the other for overlapping. If it gets too difficult to slide across, you can remove the right or the bottom end.
I did everything on 123D Design.
CCSS

Models for Multiplication Multiplication has multiple meanings. For integers, it can be repeated addition, splitting (tree, product rule for counting), or area. For fractions, it can be area or a sequence of steps for partitioning. The 3D model allows for both integer and fractional multiplications. Context matters a lot in making sense of multiplication!

• Please define or describe units (non-dimensional, linear, 2D, or even 3D) clearly.
  • To model integer multiplication, please use the small square as a non-dimensional unit for counting. For an area model, please use the small square as a 2D unit (unit square).
  • To model fraction multiplication, please define the whole board as a 2D unit (square unit). Each small square is thus 1/144 (square unit).
  • To model fraction multiplication as a sequence of actions, please use the small square as a non-dimensional unit. Example: John has 144 toys car. He gives 3/12 of them to Mary. Mary then gives 2/12 of what she gets to Katie. How many toy cars does Katie get?
    • Of course, it can be used in other ways, depending on the context.

description.text:
A mount for attaching a bike lock to a bike. The lock can only be removed by swinging around 90 degrees - so it is secure on the bike but doesn't have a catch / release mechanism. The lock swings around a little - but not enough to be a problem.

You'll need a small bolt (mine is a M4x60mm iirc) through the top hole to secure the two parts, and a shorter bolt through the bottom to secure the underneath. You might want to put a small strip of rubber / rolled up tape on the underside to prevent scratching the frame.

Obviously bike locks and frames differ quite a bit, so you might need to edit the model (blender file attached) as necessary.

Summary

This is a case for the Orange Pi Zero, a super low cost (US$7) mini computer like the Raspberry Pi Zero, but with built-in wired & wifi networking and more processing power. Perfect for using with Octoprint to control 3D printers.

  • Multiple options
  • Easy print
  • Cut-out for the pin header (for adding extra USB ports etc)

The Base

There are two options - one just the base model, one with a mounting ear (perfect for 2020 aluminium profiles).

There is a 3mm hole for fitting the antenna through.

Mount the board with four M3 6mm screws.

The Cover

There are two options - one with slot vent, one with honeycomb vent. They are otherwise the same.

The cover is friction fitted to the base with no screws needed, and is quite snug.

Printing

The STL files must be rotated before printing, with the flat side down.

Those in the pictures are printed on a Wanhao Duplicator i3, in FormFutura HD-glass see-through black PETG, with a 0.4mm nozzle, 0.28mm layer height, 3 top/bottom layers, and 3 perimetres.

description.text:
After burning up an SSR (which leaves the bed in an always on state) I switched to the TriGorilla Mosfet heat controller to relay power to my 280w heated bed (https://www.amazon.com/TriGorilla-Printer-Heating-Controller-Extruder/dp/B01HCVJ3K2). This device is pretty great and stays cool to the touch even after heating the bed to 100C. It does require more connections and just leaving it open on the floor of my FT-5 didn't seem like a good idea.

I created this case to accommodate the wire connections as well as leave plenty of room for a fan an ventilation. You will need four 12mm m3 bolts and nuts. I used 3m mounting tape to secure it to the electronics box.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Print the bottom without supports to keep the nut captures clean. Top needs supports to print.

comments.text: The bottom image on the Amazon listing at https://www.amazon.com/TriGorilla-Printer-Heating-Controller-Extruder/dp/B01HCVJ3K2 labels the connections. 'Heatbed connector' are the leads to your heated bed. 'Power input 12-24V' is power directly from your PSU. 'Connect to ramps 1.4' is the trigger - connects to where your heatbed would normally connect on a ramps/mks board. The bottom two green connectors are left open in this configuration.

author: Artesian

description.text:
This is a remix of the PSU case of the VORON core-XY printer by /u/russiancatfood

This allows using a standard Chinese PSU (198x98x42) instead of the Meanwell S-201-12 (215x115x50mm) which is expensive and difficult to find because it's discontinued. It also allows using a genuine or fake Fotek relay (60x45x22.5mm) instead of the Omiron relay (58x43x27mm).

Note that the heatbed connector is relocated a bit because the PSU case is smaller than the original one and there just isn't enough room in the original location. The IEC socket is also rotated to make space.

The PSU is only fitted with 2 screws, which is enough but not as strong as the original one.
This is a remix; I created printable version .stl files and way to connect the halves. The connection will be visible, but atleast you get it printed :)

description.text:
This character was designed from stats generated on our Wayfarer Random Alien Generator app for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and will also be used for our modular wargaming system, Wayfarer Tactics (now in Second Edition!). If you want to print a 28mm scale version, just scale it up by 166.6%.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

description.text: Well drawing inspiration from VictorFrost's Mic Holder, I created the Speedlight for Nikon. With the inspiration from Dranoweb's Swiss Army Style SD holder I combined the 3 and made a Hotshoe SD card Holder. While it swivels like the army style holder, it mounts to a Nikon Hotshoe. Printing it soon, ran out of filament but some is on the way, and ill add pics. The holder has individual inserts for full size SD, Micro, and Mini SD cards. you don't have to use all of them, just what you need. If you don't have a camera and just want a simple holder, you could print 2X top pieces and no bottom piece. Locking nuts will work best with whatever bolt/screw you use that fits.

description.text:
3D printable t-slot cover for 25mm 8020 aluminum extrusion, based off of 8020 part number 25-2112, found here.

Use it to manage or hide wires, or just make your t-slot extrusions look better. 3D printed pieces work surprisingly well. STL model is 100mm long, See printing note below for custom lengths.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100

Notes:

Can print first layer up to 0.4mm, but other layers should be finer (I used 0.2mm) to get details so the slot cover holds in the slot.

Sizing Custom Lengths
To make longer or shorter, scale along the length axis in your slicer program. For this model that should be the Y-Axis.

For particularly small pieces (like I have pictured), I recommend printing a longer 100mm piece and then cutting to length. This will give clean edges and make sure the piece sticks to the print bed well.

Cartoonish paw designed for puppets, dolls, or any other creations. The paw is symmetrical so it can be front, back, left or right.

This is our entry into the MakerBot Ornaments Challenge. This design has an overall traditional shape with stacked facets that give it an up to date look. At it's widest cross section you can see that it is derived from a snowflake's six sided crystal shape. This also looks good as just the top half as well. Printed in green it may look like a tree.  
I look forward to seeing this printed with one of the tranparent filaments (don't have any on hand here yet). If you print a clear one please share!

This model was created with 3D printing in mind, so the layers stack cleanly. We recommend printing this design with 0% fill and just one extra shell, at 0.2 layer thickness or thinner. This keeps it very translucent. No support needed.  
Simply align and glue the two identical halfs together.  
There is space inside for an LED and battery, if your so inclined to hack this.

title: Da Vinci 1.0 Pro D-Link Wi-Fi Camera (DCS-932L) Mount

description.text:
This camera mount is for Da Vinci 1.0 Pro. The camera is D-Link Wi-Fi Camera (DCS-932L),

I choose this camera because of WiFi, price, and free remote viewing app. The camera can be bought for around $30-$40 on Amazon.

You can print with your own support or the use the file with the added support. The mount slides into existing cut out inside the printer. Tilt the top up against the sheet metal (on angle) and slide up, once the top is in the mount should be able to sit flat with the sheet metal. Then slide the mount down into location. The fit is tight but might requiring shaving some material off the support side, only a little at a time if you can not get the mount to slide in.

title: Xena S Chakram v2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is an update to my previous design - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1712732
per a request I received.

Was asked to split the S Chakram into 2 halves and enable magnets to be added to hold the 2 halves together.

There are 4 pieces to print. Glue the 2 halves together and there should be 4 pockets to glue in rare earth magnets - 4 mm diameter x 2.5 mm height on each side. Glue magnets into these pockets and after the glue cures, attach the 2 halves together.

I modeled the magnet pockets to accommodate these magnets - http://www.harborfreight.com/10-piece-rare-earth-magnets-67488.html

I have not printed this, nor do I immediately plan to, so please share your results.
If you want to see any updates or fixes that are needed, please let me know.

After the holidays I should have time to split these 2 halves into further halves so they can fit on a 150 mm x 150 mm print bed.

title: Plastic Bottle Cutter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I saw the Plastic Bottle Cutter Kickstarter and their website;

https://plasticbottlecutter.com/

Basically you can take any plastic bottle and make cordage out of it. Which is useful when you are out of civilization and need cordage. 10 loops from a 2 liter bottle can tow a car. It's also a great way to reuse plastic soda bottles. If you make the strips thin enough you can weave it into multi strand rope, or a belt, or fabric. With heat from a heat gun it shrinks to fit any surface exactly. So you can make plastic handle protectors for all your tools. Just wrap the plastic cordage around the handle and hit it with the heat gun for a few seconds.

But $50 (US) for shipping one of them to me wasn't really economical. So I modeled it in Tinkercad and printed it out on the Zortrax printer we have in the shop.

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/43nrR97T5VQ-plastic-bottle-cutter/editv2?sharecode=5iGMymW9r71yHxGpc7c_yf6E1O2qkjvKbm3xAu2weOs=

The center is meant to be held upright and the horizontal slot is for a piece of a 9mm snap off blade. The slider then slides onto the center piece. The hole in the back is meant for a M5 thumb screw. My intention is to thread the hole with a tap.

Additional Materials you will want:
1 9mm snap off knife blade (they have them at every hardware and craft stores as well as at WallyWorld)
1 M5 Thumb screw (I think they have these at that hardware store that is named after a playing card, but I ordered mine online from SneezeBay)

I've tested this and it's working pretty well so far. I don't have the thumb screw in it yet, I gotta get to the hardware store for that.

comments.text: I printed mine out of PLA. That's the only plastic I have at the moment. The bottle cut right through the slider while I was "threading" my first bottle. I will print another slider using a strong plastic. What plastic did you used?

author: DrPeper

description.text:
This is a clamp holder for an angle finder. It is used to accurately make offset bends on 1.5in roll cage tubing.

Parts needed to assemble after printing:

  • Angle finder
  • Bolts
  • Magnets
  • Brass inserts

Assembly instructions:

  1. Use a vice to press the brass inserts into the upper clamp.
  2. Glue the ring magnets into the slots in the upper clamp (make sure the polarity matches the magnets on the angle finder).
  3. Slip both clamps over the roll cage tube to be bent.
  4. Use the M6 bolts to tighten the clamp in place.
  5. Simply plop the angle finder onto the magnets and zero it!

title: Hershey Bar holder for the freezer

description.text:
Mmmm, frozen Hershey bars.  I prefer almond, but regular's good too.  Great in summer, but good all year long.  
This bin slides over the rail on the freezer door and hold about ten candy bars, with a divider to help them stand upright (or to separate the almond from the regular).  
If you print one of these and use it to hold something other than Hershey bars in your freezer... I probably won't object.  Too much.  :)
Oh boy, is this gonna need supports.  I couldn't get the entire bracket part to survive the removal of supports, but what was left still worked.

description.text:
This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1387821/#remixes. I was tired of having to re-solder the wires to my heated bed after them coming loose, and after the 4th time of it, I figured there had to be something better.

I found the piece made by Antscran which looked awesome, but didn't quite fit my bed, plus I didn't really want to take anything apart to solve this problem. So I took his idea and parsed it down and came up with this. It's probably no where near as sturdy, but so far it's been great for me so far and just slipped right onto one of the bars on the bottom side of the bed, and just needed to be all the way to the side to avoid hitting the Y-axis motor. A couple of zip ties on top keeps the wires in place and puts the straight back and away from the connection.

A Nice cnc Rauter Mill Frame For beginners to start with :)
The frame must of course be adapted or be changed if necessary,to the vision / ideas /requirements of the builder. but the frame serves actually rather as an example for the one who wants to build a cnc mill for the first time.

Very small router table, using a Makita Handheld Router*. I originally made it larger, but had to make it smaller to be printable from a single 1kg spool (it uses about 1kg of plastic). I've been using it with fillet templates and flush trim router bits* to cut panels for an adaptive kayak seat the Environmental Traveling Companions are making.

After printing, parts of the clamp may need to be separated from the shell with a small spatula. There are spots for two small M3 socket cap screws under the clamp to prevent it from wearing in those spots.

The rubber base is optional, as is the geared wheel (the wheel can get jammed from material falling into the gears so it may be better to leave it out).

I also added a Mini Router Table, which is larger than the one in the picture (240mm across instead of 180mm - I haven't tried printing the larger version).

title: Prusa i3 MK2/S/3 Filament Spool Holder ClipOn

description.text:
The Prusa i3 MK2/S is a great printer, but the filament spool holder could be better.

I redesigned the original to:

  • Support a tube instead of taps to hold filament spools... and more than one spool support.
  • Easy attach the Prusa frame with ClipOn as in Prusa i3 MK2/S/3 Filament Guide ClipOn
  • Filament storing holes for holding unused filaments.

The tube I use is standard electrical 20mm PVC tube that snaps into the holder. In case you like the original tab based style, I included models for that too (no tube needed).

For tube holders, the left and right holder is identical, just print two.

If you need another tube size, leave a comment and I will upload model for that size.

Based on the Original Prusa i3 MK2 open source files found on GitHub.

New MK3 style design: Prusa i3 Spool Holder, Single Side ClipOn

Update:

  • Added holder for 22mm OD tubes.
  • Added holder for M8 Threaded Rod.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25% triangle

Notes:

Preferred material is PET-G, but PLA can be used. ABS will properly have corner warping problems due to the size.
For the shown parts I used 0.2mm layer height, 2 perimeters and 25% infill (triangle), 2 bottom and 3 top layers.

title: Steering Column Holster - Fits Ruger LCP / Ford Expedition '07

description.text:
This concealed holster attaches below the steering column in a 2007 expedition using existing screws and holds a Ruger LCP compact pistol. It has a fairly easy entry for the pistol but a firm grip when fully inserted. Trigger is covered when holstered, and barrel points to left side door. Holster/pistol position allows the full range of motion for the tilt wheel and obviously does not interfere with the steering wheel.

As you can see in the pics, I printed it in red and then painted black, my preference would've been to print in flat black but I didn't have the filament handy. The slots in each flank of the holster are to reduce delamination risk when printing - try it sometime, it works.

** if I were to change anything about this, I'd thicken up the top and bottom plates a little. I accidentally cracked mine a bit when I was removing the supporting material (I had done very dense support to help this big part print). I may come back around and make that change, but I don't have time tonight.

author: ivymike

title: Prusa i3 MK2/S/3 Filament Guide ClipOn

description.text:
The Prusa i3 MK2/S/3 kit comes without a filament guide - this is a problem when using stiffer filaments on small spools. The filament tend to unwind and get stuck when printing.

My filament guide is a two part solution, a base with a new ClipOn design to lock the guide to the Prusa frame and an interchangeable filament guide (loop).

The ClipOn Holder (base) it is securely locked to the aluminum frame, but still easy to re-position.
The loop has a friction fit into the holder that closes the filament loading slot and prevents the filament from escaping the loop when printing.

Selecting models:

  • Select a ClipOn Holder rectangular or angled. Angled version will prevent collisions in top Z positions.
  • Select a Loop size and if it should have filament slot.

If you often forget to put the filament through the guiding loop when loading the hot end, the guide with filament slot is the solution.

The thin part of the ClipOn base acts as a spring but is strong enough the securely hold the top part in place. I tested with PLA and PETG and both materials works great.

Let me know in the comments if you have ideas or changes to the design.

Update: Added Filament Guide Dust Clearner for ClipOn base

Don't forget to like it, if you like it...

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mmm

Infill:

30-50%

Notes:

Print with PLA, ABS, PET-G or similar.
2 perimeters, 3 top and 2 bottom layers 50% infill.
The loop should fit into the base, but you may need to smooth the loop guide surface with a knife or sand paper to get an easy friction fit into the base.

title: O Scale Rail Bogie for 28mm or 35mm tabletop wargaming.

description.text:
I picked up a second hand O scale train car and have begun designing a cheap model of the bogies for tabletop wargaming. My goal is to have a 3d printed frame and side panels made of card stock for cheap Warmachine Terrain.

*Edit 4-3-17 - I get some many hits on this that I feel I aught to finish it. the holdup is that my printer died and I've been in process of getting a new printer setup. New printer is an ANET A8. I also picked up some second hand Lionel train cars to look at for design. And I've learned a few tips and tricks for Openscad that might make this a better model. Look for a v2.0 soon.

*Edit 10-18-17 - I want to honorably mention this guy:
https://www.thingiverse.com/Depronized/about
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2235152
When I started doing these bogies, I had a Micro3d that could barely do the job. I was fumbling through learning Openscad, and there was nothing else out there. Now I see work like this guy has done and I want to change mine to be like his. So when I pick this up again, expect to see it as a remix. I want to do a version that does not need external parts. A 1 plate full 3d printed bogie.

Printer:

Micro3d

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

med-high

Infill:

enough to make a solid part

Notes:

Wheels are separate from axles and need to be pressed or hammered on. I designed it like that to hide the print bed surface of the parts, as well as make printing easier. Use some kind of wire for the actual axle. You may have to fiddle with it to get the axle assembly into place.

Yes, I have printed a handfull of prototypes of these. This is a long way from being complete.

Update 12-5-16
Latest print was a terror for assembly. I will have to redesign the press fit axle wheel connection.

author: Swift2568

description.text:
This is my entry into the MakerBot Ornaments Challenge.  
The 2D printable ornament that turn into a 3D pyramid by bending the triangles along the guidelines.  
Can be produced either by 3D printer (printing time less than 8 minutes with scale 1) or cutting plotter.  
Ideal to make a very attractive and fast decoration.  
Use the holes on top to hang the pyramid to the three or a rope. In alternative you can also wrap it around a led light to make it shine (as I did on my 3D printer :) )

Print and fold, one shell is enough!  
@ scale 1 the result is a pyramid 50mm tall  
If you plan to use it with a LED light inside, consider printing with translucent material.

title: Mr Freeze's Freeze gun from Batman: The Animated Series

description.text:
Update I've added the upper Freeze gun Body piece which has slots to allow the glowing blue power source light (LEDs and acrylic rods) to be seen. I have also created a ammo clip that will have glowing blue rods in the center. Not the exact model from the animated series, I have added some more details to make it appear a little more "realistic". I will be printing in the not too distant future, but I have to work out wire, battery and LED space/mounting.
Another design for my son's comic-book themed bedroom. We are going for a Batman-like set of trophies. First, the Kryptonian Command Key display (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:183508) and now Mr Freeze's infamous Freeze gun. Designed nearly all from scratch (other than a borrowed AR15 grip), this model will eventually have a glowing blue power tube/barrel and a glowing blue ammo clip all lit up with LEDs.
Stay tuned as the design progresses - it's not complete yet but I thought it looked too cool not to share, even if it's not done. I am also going to model a nice display stand to hold it - this thing is going to be a huge prop - over 12" long.

author: NJS96

title: Monoprice Maker Select 3D Printer v2 Spool Holder Extention

description.text:
This is an a longer version of the spool holder that is shipped with the Monoprice Maker Select 3D Printer v2 printer. This should allow you to use larger spools that will not fit on the factory holder.

Printing Reccomendations

  • Print with raft bed.
  • Printing with only bed supports will work just fine but there is two overhangs that could be helped with full supports. Your call. I was able to print with only bed supports.
  • Print slightly slower than normal if you have time. This will be holding a bit of weight so you will want good forming around the locking lugs.
  • You will need to do some sanding after the print. The locking lugs and bolt face are set for a very tight fit. You may need to sand things down and round some edges to get it to fit.

Sketchup model is included for tweaking. Good Luck.

comments.text: Hi.  just ordered the 3d Select Plus version and I will need this spool extension.  What does the creator mean when he says to "print with raft bed"?  I am new to all of this.
comments.author: Otolith

comments.text: In your slicer there is an option for what is called a "raft".  It tells the slicer to put down a few layers of filament to create a level print platform and improve the adherence of the part to the bed.  When the part is completed you should be able to break the raft away with a bit of force.  It does use a bit of extra filament but it helped me early on to get experience and to get my printer dialed in.  If your bed is properly leveled, however you could do without it in this case.
comments.author: Otolith

comments.text: Had to do some sanding and use a small washer (from a BB30 cycling bottom bracket) to hold it tight, and I extended it by 5mm, but it works like a champ now to hold a SainSmart TPU filament spool.  THANKS!

print_settings.Notes:: The torso piece had a lot of support due to the angle I printed it at - you could rotate to use less

title: Laureline - Ball Joint Doll (1/4 MSD BJD scale)

description.text:
This is a work in progress Ball Joint Doll (BJD).

Laureline will stand around 45cm tall when finished, which is 1/4 scale (MSD size).
She is strung together using 2mm round elastic.

So far I have only completed the lower half of the doll - the hip to upper leg joint is a bit tight, and I will likely join the hip and upper leg back into a single piece in the next version.

The knees in this design are separate pieces and fit snugly with the upper and lower leg pieces, allowing a wide range of pose-ability while still being able to support the weight of a larger doll.

All of the leg pieces are for the right leg only - mirror these to print the parts for the left leg.

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

Printed on fast setting with default infill and generated support, the print times / materials costs are as follows:

foot: 37 mins 6.4 g

lower leg: 1 hr 24 mins 15.7 g

knee: 33 mins 5.2 g

upper leg: 1 hr 50 mins 20.7 g

hip: 1 hr 26 mins 15.8 g

torso bottom: 4 hr 26 mins 55.4 g

The torso piece had a lot of support due to the angle I printed it at - you could rotate to use less

remixed_from.author: omegatron
remixed_from.title: Flashforge Creator Pro Glass Adjustable Bed Bracket (MOD)

title: Flashforge Creator Pro Glass Adjustable Bed Bracket with bolt action and duplo threads

description.text:
I made a couple changes from the original. First, I changed the design of the nut from being nob-like to a hex shape like an actual nut (basically, I had to remodel these pieces from scratch and it was hard to reproduce the nob texture but easy to make a simple hex :D). Second, and most importantly, I re-threaded both the pin and nut so that they are significantly larger and less prone to stripping through repeated use.

A glass platform is perfectly flat, so the original design should work well to hold one in place. However, I was using a flexible platform from PrintInZ (Zebra flex plate). This platform needed to have all four corners clamped down with some degree of pressure to keep the platform perfectly flat throughout an entire print. After stripping and re-printing several replacement pins and nuts, I decided to make this remix.

I've also included the original corner pieces for completeness, although they were not changed from the original.

Enjoy!

description.text: Allows Orion owners to extend the length of their spool holder without replacing the entire piece, which is too big to print on an Orion. This is usefull if you have a larger 5 lbs spool that won't fit on the standard holder.

I'm doing a re-theme of an old EM pinball and needed a way to get light from a Neopixel below the playfield surface to above it for lighting up playfield plastics. This thing is a mount for a 5mm diameter light pipe to fit onto a Neopixel that I cut from a light strip.

The light pipe mount has notches in the base to fit over the solder legs and the small chip capacitor next to the LED. It's a tight press fit for mounting over the LED and a tight press fit for the light pipes I picked up surplus from a local Dallas area store.

It took many variations to get this working. Translucent filament is terrible for light pipes and hollow tubes of 3D filament just allow light to escape. A light pipe is the best way to go and this mount makes it easy.

author: falconman

title: Pulse Motor(s) for Zero Back emf Experiment
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The original design of this motor should be credited to the late John Bedini. Although I had never met this genius, he has given me so much inspiration and hope. Also, I would like to give a special thanks to Peter L. who I am sure has put a lot of work and thought into this technology. Thanks to the moderators of Energy Science Forum who give an avenue to discuss this technology.

Disclaimer: This work can be a danger to your health. Catastrophic failure of parts spinning at high speed can cause injury to people, property, and death. Build and experiment at your own risk.

This is my attempt at the motor seen in this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XQzcYZk9MWA

It is discussed in this forum in more detail: http://www.energyscienceforum.com/showthread.php?t=3384

It is made to fit 1/4" X 3/4" X up to 7/32" deep bearings
1/4" shaft

You pick the pulsing method/ circuit and magnet wire.

The two magnet rotor is for 1/2" X 1/4" magnets. This may be updated in the future.

The holes to attach the top mount is for 6-32 bolts.

This is a small scale version. It is about 4 inches square.
As of 12:30 AM on 12/05/2016 I have not built this yet.

12/05/2016 at 11:07 AM est: added two more rotor options with corresponding reed/hall switching rotors. The magnets for the rotors are 1/2" X 1/4" disc magnets. The reed/hall magnets are 1/8" X 1/4"D cylinder magnets. I cut pieces of 1/4" inch tube to use as bearing stand-offs. Once you determine which set-up that you want to use permanently you can lightly sand the shaft and apply a minimum amount of Gorilla Glue to secure the rotor. When you print either the 4 mag rotor or the 6 mag rotor you will need to print with support on the bottom. There is a stand-off on the bottom of the rotors. You may need to run a drill bit through some of the holes to ensure a good clean fit.

12/08/2016 With some encouragement I decided to add the 2nd version which seems to be closer to Peter's replication. The coils take up two 90 degree sections of 360 degrees. The rotor here is 2.25" inches radius. The magnet sizes, shaft, bearing, and bolts are the same as version one. This print will be more difficult. You will need to use support on the coil piece and rotor. With the adapter horizontally stacking multiple motors are possible.

description.text:
This has not been test printed yet so there are no guarantees about fit. It's designed to be used by sticking it to a vertical surface somehow. I wrote a cheesy poem years ago called Ode to the Floppy Disk, and thought of it when making this. I didn't have the original words so I made some new ones. There's a version without the poem if you prefer. If anyone tries printing this I'd love to hear the results, otherwise I plan to update when I get around to printing and possibly editing this. I think eventually I'll make a version that's meant to just sit flat and a completely textless version too.

Edit: I completed two partial prints but canceled due to hardware issues. I found that the cards do seem to fit, a bit loosely if anything, and that the text on the front shows up legibly but the poem does not (on my printer at 0.1mm resolution at least).

Edit: I finally got around to completing it. I'm happy to say it works as intended. The fit is a bit loose but gravity holds things in and that makes it easier to pull them out. A photo of the completed model was added.

Replica of a public art installation in downtown Indianapolis.

description.text:
This spool holder is designed for a C/D-bot (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:500041, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001065) to mount the spool at the top rear of the printer for direct drive extruders. Can be configured for single or multiple spools.

Printed Parts:
1x Left Frame
1x Right Frame
2 x Bearing spacers (per spool)
2 x Holder retainers (per spool, 2 sizes 26-38mm and 50-64mm)

Extra parts required:
4x M8 Nuts (+2 extra per extra spool)
130mm M8 threaded rod (320mm for 2 spools etc) - any length will do really.
2 x 608ZZ bearings (per spool)
4x M5 t-nuts (to mount to 2040 T or V rail)
4x M5x10 socket head bolts (to mount to 2040 T or V rail)

Need it printed out? Then try this guy out, he's a great guy ;)

description.text:
Small wall thickness test prints that also have some small features that can be scrutinized to see how they affect the walls, to help design decisions for feature thicknesses and feature transitions when you need tighter tolerances.

WallPrintTest.STL is designed with 0.5mm, 1.0mm, 1.5mm, 2.0mm, 2.5mm and 3.0mm walls. WallPrintTestThin.STL is designed with 0.6mm, 0.7mm, 0.8mm, 0.9mm, 1.0mm and 1.25mm walls. Both tests have a 2.0mm wall intersecting all the other walls at 90º.

Depending on settings, the thinnest walls may be dropped by your slicer. Using Cura with a TAZ 6 caused the 0.5mm wall (on WallPrintTest.STL - the one on the left in the photo) not to print, but all other walls (o.6mm and up) printed in both files.

By comparing the thickness of the printed walls with the designed thickness, you can get a good idea of how much wider the print will be than the designed size, and adjust your design to produce more accurately sized prints.

title: Saucer Spittoon
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I recently got a request for a spittoon. Unhappy with designs commercially available and here on thingiverse, I decided to design one custom for the purpose. Meant to sit on a desk and be grabbed roughly without thought. I know the people this is designed for wanted something resistant to spills, so I made the sides at 45 degree angles to the bottom. Probably needs some weight in the bottom, glued in washers, whatever. It doesn't want to tip over due to the angle of the base. 1/2 full of water and it doesn't spill on its "side".
4 shells and 3 top and bottom layers each prints fine.
Sort of a torture test maybe due to the 45's, but it printed for me really well.

NOTE: I do not advocate the use of tobacco products, I think they're unhealthy and will make you smell like poo. That said, if you want to pay me to design you something, that's another story XD

title: Customizable Camera Mount for FlexRC Mini Owl Quadcopter

description.text:
This is a customizable camera mount intended for use on the FlexRC Mini Owl quadcopter. While intended for the Mini Owl, it could probably also be used for the full-sized Owl quadcopters, with appropriate customization via the Customizer. (I do not have a full-size Owl to try it on, but if anyone wants to send me one to test, I'm happy to do so! ;-) It might also be adaptable to other double-plate quads like the Lumenier, etc.

The height, width, depth, thickness, hole sizes for camera lens and mounting posts, camera position fore/aft, and camera angle can all be customized. (For instance, my camera has a built-in VTX, so needs to be positioned a little bit forward, so that the props clear the camera body. I also like a little bit of upward angle on my camera - as shown in the photo from the side.) Note that camera angles will affect how thick the mount wall needs to be - a steeper angle will require a thinner wall, while a flatter angle will allow a thicker wall - some measurement and experimentation may be required to find the best fit.

The mount will print in an upper half and lower half, for clamping around the camera lens neck. It prints with the lens mounting hole halves facing upward, so no support material is needed. The 'Print Offset' parameter specifies the Y-axis distance on the print bed between the two printed halves of the mount. (Should be fine at its default value, but if you need to change it, you can.)

I'm a big fan of printing holes a bit undersized, and drilling/reaming out with a drill bit post-print, as the drill bit tends to provide a much more precise hole size.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

I like to keep it light, so I use 20%

After printing, pass the mating surfaces across some fine sandpaper or a fine file, to be sure that the surfaces will mate up snugly and squarely.

Drill out the column holes to the needed diameter (I use a #29 drill bit for my Mini Owl support posts.)

Place the two halves, with the prepared mating surfaces together and carefully aligned as they will hold the camera, in a vise. Use an appropriately-sized drill bit (I do it by hand, just turning the bit by hand) to open up the lens mounting hole to the smallest size that will clamp fully around the camera lens neck. If you printed the mount to hold the camera at an angle, be sure to preserve that angle while cleaning up the mounting hole with the drill bit.

Paying attention to which half should be on the top and bottom (if you printed it an upward or downward angle), slide one half onto the frame posts, position the camera in the mounting hole of that half, then slide the other half over the posts and position the camera as needed (be sure it is not rotated toward one side or the other.) Snug everything down with the frame bolts, and you should be all set.
This was designed using the ever-awesome OpenSCAD CSG tool, which is why it is customizable.

The iBrick is a set of two lego pieces that you can use to incorporate your iPhone into your lego creations. Use it to make a case, or a phone holster, or a castle with an iPhone in the side. The possibilities are endless!

Print out the top and bottom part. Place your iPhone in the bottom part. If you want to encase your iPhone as shown in the image, you'll need 24 2x2 lego bricks. If you don't have any, print some of these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5699 Stack 12 lego bricks on either side of the phone building up from the bottom part. You should now be able to put the top part in place and have it line up with the top of the iPhone. Add other lego bricks as desired.

Blender :)
Detail from table hockey. Printed without supports.

Dimensions accurately fit my stool,so probably not yours.  
The "softness" comes from a rubber O-ring half-embedded in the base.  
It took several tries to get this right -- the o-rings I got were not /exactly/ the size they said on the box, and my initial thought was to leave them half-embedded.  In the end ( after about 5 tries) I found it better to make a deeper groove.  
Printing wasn't perfect -- the bed wasn't hot enough and it suffered from base-curl and slight splitting 1/3 of the way up.  Nothing unglueable however, and adequate.
print in ABS.  Glue o-ring in the annular slot.  Hot-glue to the legs.

comments.text: Hi! how are you? I am from Argentina and I found that printer, and love it the form factor, but, the important thing, it worth? 350 dollars at today, I would like to hear to honest opinion, thanks in advance!
comments.author: cronosgba

comments.text:
Its a great little printer. Print quality is good. But its has a very small print area and the bed is a real pain to level.
It got me started in 3d printing, but I'm glad I have moved on the the Prusa i3, a lot easier!
Go for something in your budget, and is easy to bed level, and will have a large enough print area to keep you happy on the future.

title: Modified e-cigar mouth tip part, from ego-t model to ego-c

description.text: Thiniverse user sOnGoKu had made an e-cigar replacement mouth piece part for an eGo-C cigar. I had an eGo-T with missing mouth piece, so I took the STL file and modified it so that it would fit to the eGo-T. I just scaled it larger, 121%, for perfect fit, and cut 5.5mm of extra length away so that the part goes fully inside. It is working well and it is like the official part.

title: Scalar M Ramps 1.4 Box With 60mm Fan

description.text: I added two attachments to the box to install it to the Scalar printer easily. Also added 10mm height to the lower part. Fan mount holes were a little above according to the stepper drivers in original one. I pulled it to the middle to make air distribution more balanced. Also made holes on the sides to close the top section via cable ties. I think this is the easiest way according to the screwed design.

Arduino Mega Size Discrepancies

In the original design, after printing it, I realized that altough my original Mega didn't fit because of the USB and Power connectors positioned laterally, my clone Arduino Mega suited it perfectly. So I redesigned it and changed the positions of the holes according to the original Mega which was written "Designed in Italy" on the back. So please be aware of this discrepancy and make sure your dimensions are suitable for this case.

description.text:
This is a printable outline for the cork underlay I created for my MP Select Mini 3D Printers.

Print the PDF on a standard 8.5"x11" Letter sized sheet of paper and use it to cut out your foam and cork. Attach together and insert under the bed, enjoy!
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/PxtzV4mzEbg" ></iframe>

comments.text: I had a slight issue making this. It seems my cork/foam combo was just a bit too thick, and caused the build plate to bow in the middle. I solved this by stepping on the insulation a bit, which crushed down the foam. I'm hoping that the repeated heating will slowly cause the foam to bounce back, because right now I've got an approximate 1/16th inch air gap between the bed and the cork. I would recommend using a slightly softer foam.

comments.text: man, this is a good case, it protects the bottom battery hatch from any water (unless i guess you print the one without the bottom on it). Sometimes i set my mod down in the kitchen and accidentally hit some wet surface. It also widens the bottom and makes it stand up easier, all around a sturdy case. I've printed 2 of these now in ABS and I only take them off to change the battery or clean them, they come on and off easily too. these should just come with this mod when you buy it :P

This is a remix of the control board case of the VORON core-XY printer by /u/russiancatfood

This allows using a MKS Gen 1.4 board instead of the RAMPS 1.4.

My design skills are obviously not as great as /u/russiancatfood's, so this remix is far from perfect. But it works well nonetheless.

The top has a big slot rather than a hole to run the harness and extra cables, so that the stepper motor cables can come out from the top too.

comments.text:
Thank you very much
it's just the job I was looking for for my MKS gen 1.4

description.text:
First take on an enclosure for a Speeduino (http://speeduino.com) v0.3.x board.

Hardware required is 4 M3x50 cap screws and matching nuts.

7th December 2016 - Updated with better alignment and a version of the bottom that includes mounting feet.

4th March 2018 - Minor revision to fix small alignment issues with the feet. Thicker walls and slightly smaller MAP hole.

description.text:
Made from just 2 parts you can print any size sphere you want. Or print out a few and make reflector. Look forward so seeing what you make with it. Let me know if you want to change it. I would be happy to customise it for you.  
Enjoy

This shell was designed for a 2" outside diameter. If you need a different size, just scale by that.  
You will need to print (20) 6 sided shapes and (12) 5 sided shapes.

This is my version of Cable Clip.

Work in progress
All comments and suggestions are welcome.
This is my first project, so please take this into account.

Height is adjustable.

Cutouts with circular shape on both parts are going to make connection safe and strong.

Maximum cable diameter is 7mm

You can use it for tables with heights from 15 mm to 55 mm.

https://b2b.partcommunity.com/community/partcloud/index#!part?name=Cable+Clip+(2nd+model)&model_id=47917
